Reference Text: <S ssid="1" sid="108">Here we discuss the output of Boxer on the Shared Task Texts (Bos, 2008).</S><S ssid="1" sid="93">The output of Boxer for this text is shown in Figure 3.</S><S ssid="1" sid="155">Boxer is a wide-coverage system for semantic interpretation.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="108">Here we discuss the output of Boxer on the Shared Task Texts (Bos, 2008).</S><S ssid="1" sid="64">In the context of this paper, Boxer was put into action after using a combined processing pipeline of the C&C tools consisting of POS-tagging, named entity recognition, and parsing (Curran et al., 2007).</S><S ssid="1" sid="2">Used together with the C&C tools, Boxer reaches more than 95% coverage on newswire texts.</S><S ssid="1" sid="8">Boxer is distributed with the C&C tools and freely available for research purposes.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="0">Wide-Coverage Semantic Analysis with Boxer</S><S ssid="1" sid="1">Boxer is an open-domain software component for semantic analysis of text, based on Combinatory Categorial Grammar (CCG) and Discourse Representation Theory (DRT).</S><S ssid="1" sid="11">Based on Discourse Representation Theory (Kamp and Reyle, 1993), Boxer is able to construct Discourse Representation Structures (DRSs for short, informally called “boxes” because of the way they are graphically displayed) for English sentences and texts.</S><S ssid="1" sid="3">The semantic representations produced by Boxer, known as Discourse Representation Structures (DRSs), incorporate a neoDavidsonian representations for events, using the VerbNet inventory of thematic roles.</S><S ssid="1" sid="155">Boxer is a wide-coverage system for semantic interpretation.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="2">Used together with the C&C tools, Boxer reaches more than 95% coverage on newswire texts.</S><S ssid="1" sid="64">In the context of this paper, Boxer was put into action after using a combined processing pipeline of the C&C tools consisting of POS-tagging, named entity recognition, and parsing (Curran et al., 2007).</S><S ssid="1" sid="164">It is distributed with the C&C tools for natural language processing (Curran et al., 2007), which are hosted on this site: http://svn.ask.it.usyd.edu.au/trac/candc/wiki/boxer</S><S ssid="1" sid="108">Here we discuss the output of Boxer on the Shared Task Texts (Bos, 2008).</S><S ssid="1" sid="8">Boxer is distributed with the C&C tools and freely available for research purposes.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="39">Finally, it also allows us to characterize the meaning of thematic roles independently of the meaning of the verb that describes the event.</S><S ssid="1" sid="35">The standard version of DRT formulated in Kamp & Reyle incorporates a Davidsonian event semantics (Kamp and Reyle, 1993), where discourse referents can also stand for events and be referred to by anaphoric expressions or constrained by temporal relations.</S>

<S ssid="1" sid="10">Boxer is an open-domain tool for computing and reasoning with semantic representations.</S><S ssid="1" sid="1">Boxer is an open-domain software component for semantic analysis of text, based on Combinatory Categorial Grammar (CCG) and Discourse Representation Theory (DRT).</S>
<S ssid="1" sid="8">Boxer is distributed with the C&C tools and freely available for research purposes.</S>
